name: Innocence Project

theoryOfChange: By using DNA evidence to prove innocence, the organization not only frees individuals but identifies systemic failures (like misapplied science or false confessions) to drive policy reform that prevents future wrongful convictions.

evaluationSources: New research on death investigations and forensic methods

baseline_narrative.amal_score_rationale: The organization maintains excellent financial health and transparency, though its specialized legal focus results in a high cost per direct beneficiary and lower alignment with traditional humanitarian aid priorities.

dimension_explanations.alignment: The project focuses on domestic justice reform, which is categorized as a domestic poverty and civil rights urgency [1]. While it offers a reputable pathway for sadaqah, the alignment score is medium (16/50) because the mission is specialized toward legal reform rather than direct service for the most vulnerable global populations [7].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization demonstrates high effectiveness in systemic change, achieving a significant number of exonerations through DNA evidence and legal advocacy [4][5]. While the cost per beneficiary is calculated at $86,746.42, this reflects the intensive resources required for long-term litigation and policy shifts [2]. The project maintains a program expense ratio of 74.6%, ensuring the majority of its $32,455,846 in total revenue supports its core mission [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Innocence Project works to exonerate the wrongly convicted and reform the criminal justice system through DNA testing and policy advocacy.
strengths: Exceptional fundraising efficiency of $0.11 per $1 raised
Strong liquidity with 41.7 months of working capital
baseline_narrative.summary: The Innocence Project Inc is a national nonprofit dedicated to freeing innocent individuals and preventing future wrongful convictions [2]. The organization operates through post-conviction litigation and systemic policy reform to address flaws in the justice system [1][3].

impact_evidence.evidence_grade_explanation: The organization provides direct, verifiable evidence of impact through <cite id="4">documented exonerations</cite> and <cite id="10">legislative victories</cite>.
impact_evidence.theory_of_change_summary: The Innocence Project uses DNA evidence to prove innocence, which simultaneously exposes systemic failures, providing the leverage needed to pass laws that prevent future wrongful convictions.
impact_evidence.why_evidence_matters: In legal advocacy, evidence of exoneration is the ultimate proof of a successful intervention.

long_term_outlook.room_for_funding_explanation: While the organization has <cite id="2">$91 million in net assets</cite>, the scale of wrongful convictions in the US remains a massive, under-addressed challenge.

strengths.detail: The organization holds a <cite id="1">perfect overall score of 100/100</cite> from Charity Navigator, reflecting top-tier transparency and governance.
The project demonstrates remarkable efficiency, spending only <cite id="1">$0.11 to raise every $1</cite> in charitable contributions.
With <cite id="1">41.7 months of working capital</cite>, the organization possesses significant long-term financial sustainability to pursue multi-year legal battles.

strengths_deep_dive: The Innocence Project's strength lies in its dual-track approach of individual exonerations and systemic reform. While it has achieved <cite id="5">200 people exonerated</cite> by 2017, its policy work has led to hundreds of legislative changes. This impact is supported by a <cite id="1">100% independent board</cite> and a <cite id="1">perfect score in Leadership and Adaptability</cite>. Their financial health is further evidenced by <cite id="2">$105,843,645 in total assets</cite>, providing a massive endowment-like cushion for their high-stakes legal work.
rich_narrative.summary: The Innocence Project is a national nonprofit organization dedicated to exonerating the wrongly convicted through DNA testing and reforming the criminal justice system to prevent future injustice. Founded in <cite id="1">1992</cite>, the organization has grown into a leading legal and policy institution that has helped achieve <cite id="4">over 220 exonerations</cite> as of recent reporting cycles. The organization operates a multi-pronged strategy including <cite id="10">post-conviction litigation, policy reform, and strategic litigation</cite> to address systemic flaws such as eyewitness misidentification and false confessions. Financially, the organization is exceptionally robust, maintaining a <cite id="1">perfect 100.0/100 from Charity Navigator</cite>. In the 2023 tax year, the Innocence Project reported <cite id="2">$32,455,846 in total revenue</cite>, with a significant portion of its funding coming from <cite id="2">$26,644,804 in public contributions</cite>. The organization maintains a <cite id="1">program expense ratio of 74.6%</cite>, ensuring that the vast majority of donor funds are directed toward its core legal and advocacy missions. Beyond direct litigation, the project serves as a critical research hub, utilizing <cite id="10">data science and research</cite> to identify trends in wrongful convictions and advocating for legislative changes across the United States.
